ca.uqac.lif.ecp.statechart

Class Statechart<T extends Event>

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.uqac.lif.ecp.statechart.Statechart<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the events (i.e. the transition labels)
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AtomicStatechart

    public class Statechart<T extends Event>
extends java.lang.Object
    Representation of a UML statechart. Currently, the implementation of UML statecharts imposes the following constraints and peculiarities:
    • A transition cannot cross the boundary of an orthogonal region. However, transitions from the box surrounding a group of orthogonal regions to somewhere else are allowed.
    • If no transition can fire on a given input event, the statechart moves to an implicit "trash" state and stays there forever. This propagates upwards, so a statechart enclosed within another one will provoke the same effect on its "parent" statechart.
    Author:
    Sylvain Hall√©

    • Method Detail

      • setVariable

        public Statechart<T> setVariable(java.lang.String name,
                                 java.lang.Object value)
        Sets the value of a state variable. If the variable does not yet exist in this statechart, the value this variable is given is kept as the "initial" value. When resetting the statechart (or cloning it), the variable will be set back to this value.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the variable
        value - The value of the variable
        Returns:
        This statechart

        Returns:
        This statechart

      • getAnyAtomicChild

        public State<T> getAnyAtomicChild()
        Returns an arbitrary state of this statechart that is not a NestedState. The method recurses inside nested states if the statechart only has nested states. This method is mostly used for the graphical rendering of a statechart.
        Returns:
        A state, or null if no such state exists

      • getAnyAtomicChild

        public State<T> getAnyAtomicChild(State<T> state)
        Returns an arbitrary state of this statechart that is not a NestedState and is contained within the state given as argument. This method is mostly used for the graphical rendering of a statechart.
        Parameters:
        state - The state in question
        Returns:
        A state, or null if no such state exists

      • getCurrentConfiguration

        public Configuration<T> getCurrentConfiguration()
        Gets the identifier of the current state of the statechart. If that state is itself a box containing a statechart, its state is also returned, and so on recursively. Therefore, this method returns a list of state IDs, with the first element being the ID of the top-most state, followed by the ID of the inner state (if any), and so on.
        Returns:
        The list of state IDs

      • reset

        public Statechart<T> reset()
        Resets the statechart to its initial configuration
        Returns:
        This statechart

      • findOwner

        public static Statechart<?> findOwner(Statechart<?> statechart,
                                      java.lang.String var_name)
        Finds the statechart instance that "owns" the state variable of given name. The method starts from a statechart, and if the variable is not defined, moves up to its parent, and so on.
        Parameters:
        statechart - The statechart used as a starting point for the search.
        var_name - The name of the variable
        Returns:
        The statechart where this variable is defined, or null if the variable could not be found in this statechart, nor any of its parents

      • findOwner

        public Statechart<?> findOwner(java.lang.String var_name)
        Finds the statechart instance that "owns" the state variable of given name. The method starts from a statechart, and if the variable is not defined, moves up to its parent, and so on.
        Parameters:
        var_name - The name of the variable
        Returns:
        The statechart where this variable is defined, or null if the variable could not be found in this statechart, nor any of its parents
